nodes.text: Infinite exponential economic growth is essential and required for the survival and conservation of our economy and civilization
The two dominant perspectives on growth (anti-growth based on entropy limits, and pro-growth based on knowledge/innovation) are limited, subjective, and talk past each other
The anti-growth perspective argues nature imposes fundamental physical constraints (entropy) that make infinite growth impossible because resources and free energy will become unusable
Evidence cited for the anti-growth view: Second Law of Thermodynamics (entropy production nonnegative) and literature linking entropy production to resource depletion and environmental degradation
The pro-growth perspective argues that knowledge, ideas, and technological innovation decouple economic growth from material resource limits and can enable ongoing growth

Evidence cited for the pro-growth view: Solow-style growth theory, empirical claims that technological innovation drove regional growth (examples from China), and assertions that per-capita material intensity can fall while GDP rises

Both perspectives are flawed: anti-growth wrongly privileges entropy as ontologically primary; pro-growth relies on mind-matter dualism that unjustifiably exempts mental production from entropy and so cannot explain or manage creation

A broader explanatory frame centers on the objective universal process of creation: equilibration produces new, more powerful organizational levels (disequilibrium) that generate novel properties and enable access to new resources

Evidence and mechanisms for the creation process: combinatorics of operations (an n-number of functional operations generates about n squared combinations) yields exponential increases in organizational power; empirical examples and citations (astrophysics, biology, Bloom et al. on ideas getting harder to find)

Because conservation of a regulatory level requires access to new resources, sustaining any level (including human consciousness and civilization) requires constant creation of new exponentially more powerful organizational levels, hence exponential growth is necessary and can be infinite

Empirical correlative evidence: resource depletion, declining per-researcher productivity for new ideas (research productivity falling, requiring exponential researchers to sustain growth), and historical Malthusian-style correlations between production, consumption, resources, and population

Policy implication claim: cutting production, consumption, or population is counterproductive because underutilizing human creative capacity increases production inefficiency and drives greater material/resource use and population pressures

Conclusion and prescriptive claim: reorganize social and economic practice around the intentional, conscious harnessing and management of the process of creation (human creative capacity) to achieve sustained exponential growth and conserve higher-level organization

Method: conceptual critique, synthesis and literature review across thermodynamics, evolutionary theory, growth economics, creativity research, and empirical studies to construct an inclusive frame centered on the creation process

Limitation: the proposed creation-centered framework is primarily conceptual and philosophical; detailed empirical mechanisms for how to operationalize and measure the process of creation and its institutional implementation are underdeveloped

Final conclusion: only an infinite, exponential growth regime organized around continual creation of new organizational levels can prevent progressive environmental degradation, productivity collapse, and societal disintegration
